org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
"Intellectual merit":

The most productive research direction continued to be the study of algebraic K3 surfaces, which occupy a central place in 2-dimensional algebraic geometry, analogous to that of elliptic curves in dimension 1.  The PI continued to find and use explicit models and formulas for objects for which previous work gave theoretical existence proofs but could not exhibit actual equations.  Because of the ubiquity of K3 surfaces, this led to advances in several directions, such as new Diophantine records (some with Zev Klagsbrun) and new approaches to moduli spaces.

Research supporting or suggested by the K3 computations also produced results of independent interest, including: further uses of the algorithms for classifying quadratic forms (a classical problem in number theory and elsewhere); new upper bounds on the number of lines on an algebraic surface, and explicit models of surfaces with many lines that attain this bound; new genus-2 Jacobians with real multiplication (higher-dimensional analogues to the classical "singular moduli" such as 5280 ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(67)/3) and 360 ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(58)/4) ), partly answering a question raised by F.Fite' and X.Guitart; elliptic curves of rank as high as 17 in the Mordell family y2 = x3 + k, and related records for the 3-ranks of quadratic fields.

 

"Broader impact":

Some of the award funds were used to support the studies or travel of graduate students at Harvard working on topics related to the award project.  In addition, the PI continued to consult at the Centers for Communications Research in Princeton NJ and La Jolla CA, using his technical and problem-solving expertise to contribute to the Centers' classified mathematical work; advised and mentored undergraduate students, resulting in one joint paper (with Ashvin Swaminathan) and several undergraduate honors theses; gave expository mathematical lectures, some aimed at high school students or non-math majors in college, often featuring mathematical aspects of music; and gave numerous answers (some of which earned high "upvote" scores) on the public forums Math Overflow and Math Stack Exchange.
